repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem
Neovim doesn't support the `textDocument/documentLink` request.

## Solution
Add support for it :grinning: 

Note that this PR is based on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33500.

Closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33497
Close #33500

comment_data.body: this will trigger an error for servers that return null `target`, client is expected to `documentlink/resolve` to get it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -213,6 +213,35 @@ function M._get_urls()
   local cursor = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)
   local row = cursor[1] - 1
   local col = cursor[2]
+
+  local params = { textDocument = vim.lsp.util.make_text_document_params(bufnr) }
+  local results = vim.lsp.buf_request_sync(bufnr, 'textDocument/documentLink', params)
+
+  for client_id, result in pairs(results or {}) do
+    if result.error then
+      vim.lsp.log.error(result.error)
+    else
+      local client = assert(vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id))
+      local position = vim.lsp.util.make_position_params(0, client.offset_encoding).position
+      ---@param document_link lsp.DocumentLink
+      local link = vim.iter(result.result):find(function(document_link)
+        local range = document_link.range
+        return (position.line > range.start.line and position.line < range['end'].line)
+          or (position.line == range.start.line and position.character >= range.start.character)
+          or (position.line == range['end'].line and position.character <= range['end'].character)
+      end)
+
+      if link then
+        ---@type string
+        local target = link.target
+        if vim.startswith(target, 'file://') then

comment_data.body:
This is also called by the insert mode completion (C-XC-I), which will now trigger sync LSP requests and misbehave. vim.lsp.tagfunc had a bug just like this.

includeexpr may not be a good solution for this one: it is called when you don't want it (ins mode completion) and not always called when you do want it (e.g. C header file but found by existing include regexp heuristics)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1439,6 +1442,16 @@ function lsp.foldexpr(lnum)
   return vim.lsp._folding_range.foldexpr(lnum)
 end
 
+--- Provides an interface between the built-in client and 'includeexpr'.
+---
+--- When |gf| and related commands fail upon the first try, this will invoke the
+--- `textDocument/documentLink` LSP method to find the link under the cursor,
+--- falling back to `cfile`.
+---
+function lsp.includeexpr()
+  return vim.ui._get_urls()[1]

comment_data.body:
could this one be treated like document color? decoration with links encoded as `url` in the extmark?

then no code needed here: existing code for "gx" would just work, and the links could also be opened in the terminal via osc 8.

comment_data.body: Hmm... the thing about the document color implementation is that we need to update the extmarks as the highlights are clearly visible and need to be updated as the buffer is modified. In the case of document links the links don't correspond to a visual adornment, and so it feels expensive to trigger `textDocument/documentLink` requests for every buffer change here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -213,6 +213,35 @@ function M._get_urls()
   local cursor = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)
   local row = cursor[1] - 1
   local col = cursor[2]
+
+  local params = { textDocument = vim.lsp.util.make_text_document_params(bufnr) }

comment_data.body:
yeah, but they can be seen as visual adornments for a terminal. 

If i press ctrl-shift-o to enter URL mode so I can open them with my terminal? (or with ghostty, maybe that's a mouse).

This is an important use case if you are working over SSH, for example.

comment_data.body: can we use `t.retry` somehow instead of hardcoding a 1.5s wait?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -731,6 +732,8 @@ describe('statuscolumn', function()
         api.nvim_input_mouse('left', 'press', '', 0, 5, 8)
         eq('', eval('g:testvar'))
         api.nvim_input_mouse('right', 'press', '', 0, 6, 4)
+        -- Wait for the synchronous call of `textDocument/documentLink`
+        sleep(1500)

comment_data.body: For now I won't resolve the target and leave that as a follow-up.

comment_data.body: `t.retry` needs a stop condition, and we don't have an obvious one to use here.

comment_regular_data.body:
I had noticed this method before, but my thought at the time was to implement it using a mechanism similar to `vim.lsp.inlay_hint` (though it doesn't necessarily mean we need to provide an additional `enable`), because we can use `extmark` to tell the terminal that "there is a link here" by osc 8.

This is because, in practice, this method is similar to inlay hints and codelens (as well as document color); they all involve fetching some extmarks from the server when the document changes and displaying them on the buffer, except that the extmarks here are invisible. My previous eagerness to push forward `vim.lsp.Capability` was precisely in the hope of finding a way that would facilitate our adoption of this "enable" pattern. I am also currently considering whether code can be shared between code lens and inlay hints, which might be helpful for features like this.

> I had noticed this method before, but my thought at the time was to implement it using a mechanism similar to `vim.lsp.inlay_hint` (though it doesn't necessarily mean we need to provide an additional `enable`), because we can use `extmark` to tell the terminal that "there is a link here" by osc 8.
> 
> This is because, in practice, this method is similar to inlay hints and codelens (as well as document color); they all involve fetching some extmarks from the server when the document changes and displaying them on the buffer, except that the extmarks here are invisible. My previous eagerness to push forward `vim.lsp.Capability` was precisely in the hope of finding a way that would facilitate our adoption of this "enable" pattern. I am also currently considering whether code can be shared between code lens and inlay hints, which might be helpful for features like this.

@ofseed does your proposal differ with what @rmuir is suggesting?

> There are some good comments here, but if we don't have a clear decision on some of them, let's merge this and iterate in followup PRs or backlog issues.

I'm okay with that. I opened https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/37691 to track future work on this feature.

> > There are some good comments here, but if we don't have a clear decision on some of them, let's merge this and iterate in followup PRs or backlog issues.
> 
> If there are concerns that influence the public API wouldn't it make sense to resolve these first - given how close the 0.12 release is?

That's fair. I can make this closer to the implementation of `document_color` later this week.

> That's fair. I can make this closer to the implementation of document_color later this week.

Just to be clear, I'm not sure if the document_color approach is more appropriate here. I haven't really made up my mind or thought about it enough.

But my point is more that we've several choices like
- Use on-demand approach with `gx` retrieving document links
- Use on-demand approach that sets url extmarks
- Use auto-refresh like inlay-hints, document-color, etc. with url extmarks
- Support all 3 with configs so users can decide?

Depending on which option we pick, reverting course and changing the decision after the release means we've to deprecate APIs again unless we then decide to support both/all.
So I'd rather not rush this.

> @ofseed does your proposal differ with what @rmuir is suggesting?

No, I just mentioned that we might be able to refactor this so that these essentially similar features don't need to be implemented separately

Sleeping on this and looking at the PR more closely I think what would be unproblematic is to:

- Remove the include expression
- Remove the document link -> qf list functionality
- Keep the on-demand fetch in `gx`

In the `gx` case it's mostly implementation detail so no real public interface change and the door would still be open to later on replace it with an extmark based solution that enables osc8.

Are there any numbers of the runtime of fetching the links on a doc for a couple of servers? Would be interesting to know what kind of overhead we'd add with a constant auto refresh.
@mfussenegger that sounds like a good plan to me :)

labels.description: Nvim defaults for options, colorscheme/theme, autocmds/events, etc.
labels.name: defaults

title: feat(lsp): support `textDocument/documentLink`
